title: AB 133
content: The people of the State of California enact the following. Item 2660-013-0001 is added to the Budget Act of 2015 for transferring $173 million from the General Fund to the Traffic Congestion Relief Fund. The funds will be allocated for local Traffic Congestion Relief Program projects, trade corridor improvements, Transit and Intercity Rail Capital Program, and State Highway Operations and Protection Program by January 1, 2017. The State Highway Operations and Protection Program will receive $5,000,000, to be repaid from the General Fund as required for the 2016–17 fiscal year. Additionally, $105,000,000 is allocated for fire recovery, debris removal, and waste management to mitigate threats to public health and safety. The Director of Finance may augment funds for fire debris removal and management costs to mitigate threats to public health and safety, with approval from the Legislature. Item 6440-001-0001 of the Budget Act of 2015 is amended to allocate funds for the University of California. The Regents of the University of California endorsed a framework for long-term funding agreed upon by the Governor and the President of the University, aiming to freeze tuition for the 2015–16 and 2016–17 academic years. Reforms will be implemented to reduce costs, improve access, quality, and outcomes, including creating capacity for all campuses to serve more resident students. The Legislature intends to use funds from an increase in nonresident students to support an increase in resident student enrollment at all University of California campuses. The University of California is expected to enroll at least 5,000 more resident undergraduate students by the 2016-17 academic year. If they meet this expectation, an additional $25,000,000 will be allocated for targeted support services to improve graduation rates for low-income and underrepresented student populations. The Regents of the University of California are required to enhance budget transparency by detailing personnel categories and fund sources on the Office of the President's website. They must report to the Director of Finance and the Legislature by December 10, 2015, on allowable fund sources for education costs and factors used to determine fund allocation for educational activities. The Regents of the University of California must implement measures to reduce the university's cost structure and consider using a market reference zone that includes state employees when determining compensation for employees in the Senior Management Group. The Regents of the University of California must identify comparable positions and approve a plan with resource projections for the fiscal years 2016-2019. The plan should include assumptions provided by the Department of Finance by August 1, 2015. The Regents of the University of California must provide projections of expenditures and enrollment for the fiscal years 2016-2019, along with any necessary operational changes to align with available resources. The university must set challenging and quantifiable goals for measures outlined in the Education Code for the 2016-2019 academic years, focusing on closing achievement gaps for underrepresented populations and aligning educational attainment with workforce needs. The University of California must submit a plan by November 30, 2015, to various legislative committees regarding the allocation of funds for lease-revenue bonds and general obligation bond debt service. The Controller transfers funds upon receipt of reports on fees for lease-revenue bonds and general obligation bond debt service. $6,000,000 is allocated to labor research and education centers at Berkeley and Los Angeles campuses. The University of California allocates funds for various programs including the Wildlife Health Center, Statewide Database, San Joaquin Valley Medical Program, and planning for a School of Medicine at the Merced campus. Additionally, funds are included for the California DREAM Loan Program. The California DREAM Loan Program is funded in this item. Payments to the University of California are limited to one-twelfth of the appropriation per month. The funds cannot be used for auxiliary enterprises or athletic programs. Item 9651-001-0001 is added for Prefunding of Health and Dental Benefits for Annuitants with a budget of $240,000,000. Prefunding Health and Dental Benefits appropriation of $240,000,000 is to supplement funding for employer share of benefits as per Department of Human Resources. The Director of Finance must certify memoranda of understanding for prefunding health and dental benefits by November 1, 2016. The appropriation is available for expenditure until June 30, 2017. Section 39.00 of the Budget Act of 2015 is amended. Section 39.00 of the Budget Act of 2015 is amended to include a list of bills related to appropriations for the Budget Bill as per the California Constitution. The act is a Budget Bill under the California Constitution and will take effect immediately.
